intro: Sinapis arvensis var. schkuhriana, commonly known as the field mustard, is a biennial or annual plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with serrated, glaucous leaves that are often hairy. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Its seeds are small and can remain viable in the soil for several years, contributing to its persistence in agricultural landscapes.
